Award.AwardTitle: Bromide in Snow in the Sea Ice Zone
Award.AbstractNarration:
A range of chemical and microphysical pathways in polar latitudes, including spring time (tropospheric) ozone depletion, oxidative pathways for mercury, and cloud condensation nuclei (CCN) production leading to changes in the cloud cover and attendant surface energy budgets, have been invoked as being dependent upon the emission of halogen gases formed in sea-ice.

The prospects for climate warming induced reductions in sea ice extent causing alteration of these incompletely known surface-atmospheric feedbacks and interactions requires confirmation of mechanistic details in both laboratory studies and field campaigns. One such mechanistic question is how bromine (BrO and Br) enriched snow migrates or is formed through processes in sea-ice, prior to its subsequent mobilization as an aerosol fraction into the atmosphere by strong winds. Once aloft, it may react with ozone and other atmospheric species. Dartmouth researchers will collect snow from the surface of sea ice, from freely blowing snow and in sea-ice cores from Cape Byrd, Ross Sea. A range of spectroscopic, microanalytic and and microstructural approaches will be subsequently used to determine the Br distribution gradients through sea-ice, in order to shed light on how sea-ice first forms and then releases bromine species into the polar atmospheric boundary layer.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The high latitudes are bellwether regions of the impact of environmental factors upon global climate. The oxidizing potential of the lower atmosphere is dominated by ozone availability, but tropospheric boundary layer ozone in Polar Regions has been observed to fall dramatically in the spring. Periodic ozone depletion episodes are caused by the release of bromine, originating from bromide ions (Br-) in sea water that produces sea salt aerosol, and bromine gases (BrO and Br) which react with ozone.

In 2009, modeling work suggested that windblown snow in the sea ice zone may supply enough bromide aerosol to support this reaction. However, it was not clear whether snow can becomes salty from contact with the sea ice, and yet still be able to be mobilized by wind. The goal of this research was to examine the amount of bromide in the snow lying on and blowing across sea ice. The goals were to:

1. Measure the bulk concentration of Br- with depth in snow on sea ice, and in wind-blown surface snow, at locations that receive wind from over sea ice.

2. Understand the location of Br- in snow on sea ice, both its microstructural location and its vertical distribution relative to the sea ice-snow interface and stratigraphic layers.

3. Characterize the mobility of the upper layers of snow resting on sea ice.

4. Produce an empirical microphysical model of snow’s role in the acquisition and transport of Br- to the boundary layer.

The third and fourth goals had to be modified at the end of Year 2, because of unfavorable meteorological conditions during our six week field campaign. Snow cover on the sea ice was thin and quite variable – with many bare patches and a few areas of low (i.e. 30-40 cm) hard-packed drifts (see sample maps of snow depths). The weather was relatively calm, there was almost no fresh snowfall, and there were only two days of winds strong enough (>8 m/s) to produce significant blowing snow. Surface snow was largely hard-packed and where there was a movable upper layer, it was thin and composed of uniformly granular crystals. There were no microstructural variations of note in the snow. Thus, there was essentially no variability in the upper layers of snow lying on sea ice. However, we were successful in collecting and analyzing snow that was blown by the wind into baskets set at several heights (up to 5 meters) on our blowing snow collection tower (see photo), and from our chemical analysis of these, we can tell that lofted snow is playing a role in the Br cycle. We found that Br- became increasingly more depleted relative to Cl- with increasing height above the sea surface, thus showing that Br- is both present in blowing snow and is being depleted by the reaction with ozone. We have published these results:

Lieb-Lappen, R. M., Obbard, R. W. 2015. The Role of Blowing Snow in the Activation of Bromine over First-Year Antarctic Sea Ice. Atmos. Chem. Phys. 15: 7537-7545. doi:10.5194/acp-15-7537-2015

Toward our second goal, we are the first group to use synchrotron-based X-ray microfluorescence spectroscopy (XRF) to examine the microstructural distribution of Br in sea ice and snow, something we did during the course of three visits to the Argonne National Laboratory's Advanced Photon Source in Chocago, IL. Based on our outstanding results with this technique, we added a fifth goal:

5. To understand the microstructural location of salts with respect to sea ice microstructure.

As a basis for analysis of the XRF results, we analyzed the microstructure of our sea ice cores using thin sections (for crystal structure/grain size and shape/grain boundaries) and X-ray micro-computed tomography (microCT) (for pore structure).
